This is a bicycle mount for the generator described in thing:28762.

You can get the OpenSCAD source from my GitHub account: http://www.github.com/haydnv ; it's in mark1/mounts/bicycle. This is designed for a specific bicycle, so you'll probably need to tweak some settings to get it to fit yours. Make sure the gear on the rotor cap matches the gear on your bicycle's back wheel. You'll need:
  • 1 bicycle with the rear wheel removed (make sure to keep the axle handy). If the kickstand doesn't look sturdy enough to support a person without a rear wheel, get a sturdier replacement from a bike shop.
  • 1 electrical generator, thing:28762
  • 1 tube of gasket sealant
  • Print 1 mount, 1 mount_support_a, 1 mount_support_b, 1 rotor_cap, and 3 pins
  • Glue the rotor cap to the generator with gasket sealant and allow 2-3 hours to cure
  • Put together the mount and supports such that they fit snugly with the bicycle frame and the top hole is 12cm above the rear axle of the bicycle.
  • With the bicycle on its side, secure the generator to the mount with the pins and re-insert the bicycle axle. Secure with nuts/bolts as appropriate to your bicycle

comments.text:
Have you measured your peak output power while pedaling?
How is the printed sprocket holding up?
comments.author: cabbage_breath

comments.text: Why remove the wheel rather than spinning a smaller wheel or drum against it? This method would give you better RPM on the generator (the bicycle wheel and drum are essentially a very large gear and much smaller pinion) and it wouldn't require disassembling the bike.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: I did it with a drum and immediatly dismantled it because the sound and vibration generated by the bicycle tire is just too bothering (unless you live alone).
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: That's not a bad idea, but I wanted to keep as much as possible printable and I couldn't think of a good way to 3D-print a drum assembly. Suggestions welcome!
comments.author: whosawhatsis

title: Geared Cube, Hand Crank Edition
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Emmett's geared cube, with a hand crank. Video of pre-lubricated just off the printer version is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jfh5DNGP8tw. Printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" settings. A video of the heart version test fit is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o8CkCe5A-1w. Your cube pieces should all spin on their respective pins as easy as this before assembly. If not, follow this procedure: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:271612/#instructions.

Study "Assembly.skp". Print emmett's "CubeGears2-3.stl". If you can edit the file, you can delete one of the large corners, the center hub, and one pin before printing as these parts are not used. Clean up any stray filament in the gear holes. See Geared Heart, Motorized Edition (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:271612) for the steps I performed in loosening up the geared cube as the it must spin freely. Print all parts. While printing "Top.stl", I paused the printer at 4.2mm and changed filament from black to silver. Test fit, file, sand, etc. for smooth operation. Lubricate the gears, "Gear Wheel Hand.stl" bushing surface and "Wheel Hand.stl" bushing surface using white lithium grease or petroleum jelly before final assembly.

comments.text:
You're welcome. And if I can do it, you most certainly can do it.
Just requires about 15-30 minutes to trim all the pins and pieces so they work smoothly. I used a modeling knife and a jewelers screwdriver. Once I have a pin and piece trimmed and operating well, I make sure the pin and piece stay together.
Also, if all else fails, trim about 1/16" from the end of the pin that goes into the piece. I've found a couple of the pieces had shallower holes than the others and the tip was grinding on the bottom of the hole in the piece (found this in both the Heart and Cube gears).
comments.author: MacGyver

Part of my testing out printed CNC accessories. Recommended for light machining only -- obviously a plastic steady rest will flex more than a metal one under load. 2014-04-16 -
v0.7: So far not print-tested so there may be errors; this version is mainly fixes to issues mentioned in v0.6 changes below. v0.6: assorted cleanups -- start fixing nut sizes, lengthen 10-24 nut trap to allow use of easier to find screw. I printed this version to check it out; it has these issues:
  • 10-24 mounting nut hole slightly too large (can superglue nut in place, or shim with extra material to get it to grab)
  • One blade mounting washer's space is made a bit tight by the base
  • Blade mount nut traps would print better with membrane
    • My test print was done solid, 0.2 layer height in ABS - seems pretty sturdy; there is enough flex that I can get a few mm of movement in any direction by pushing on the top by hand... but should work fine for light work. 2014-04-06 - v0.4; Getting closer :)

Requirements For blades:
  • 3 ea. 1/4" square brass stock for the blades (I used 2" lengths, you could do a little longer). Make sure ends that will be in contact with work have burrs removed (use file or sandpaper to clean up if necessary).
  • 3 ea. 6-32 x 9/16 (or x 5/8) socket head cap screws -- other head types will work fine too
  • 3 ea. size 6 stainless washer
  • 3 ea. 6-32 nut
    • Note -- in picture I used 6-32 x 1 screws and M4 washers as that's what I had on hand. For mount:
  • 1 ea. 10-32 (or 10-24) x 2 1/2 socket head cap screw
  • 1 ea. 10-32 (or 10-24; obv. must match screw) nut
    • Printing I recommend printing solid, 0.2mm layer height. OpenSCAD notes I'm still getting up on proper OpenSCAD coding, so pardon the assorted hardcoded numbers and often bad practices. I've tried to make most of the tweak-friendly things parametric though. If you set Frame_Cutout to true, part of the outer diameter will be cut out in the resulting model, to allow work access from the side. I've stopped uploading STLs with the cutout as I feel it weakens the part more than I'd like, though some folks may find it useful.

title: Complete Downloadable Kilowatt Wind Turbine—just add magnets & wire!

description.text: This is a wind turbine designed to output 1KW under optimal conditions. It uses a 3D-printable generator, thing:28762 .

WARNING: BUILD AT YOUR OWN RISK. This wind turbine can be dangerous and has not been fully tested. You can get the source OpenSCAD files from my GitHub repo: http://www.github.com/haydnv . You'll need:
  • 1 axial flux generator, thing:28762
  • 3 blades cut from 3mm aluminum
  • 1 vane cut from 3mm aluminum
  • 1 mount_base cut from 10mm plastic or acrylic (can be printed but not by most desktop printers)
  • 1 mount_vertical cut from 10mm plastic or acrylic (likewise)
  • 1 pole_cap, printed
  • 1 rotor_cap, printed
  • 1 1" pole at least 1 meter tall
  • 1 thrust bearing, 45mm ID x 65mm OD x 15mm high
  • 1 tube of gasket sealant
    • To build:
  • Build a generator per thing:28762
  • Glue on the rotor cap with gasket sealant and allow 2-3 hours to cure
  • Insert the tabs of the vertical mount into the base of the mount
  • Secure the mount by snapping on the vane
  • Connect the mount to the stator of the generator with the pins; thread a small piece of wire through the hole on the mount side of the pins to secure.
  • Place the pole_cap on the pole and the bearing on the pole_cap
  • Place the turbine on the bearing
  • Insert the blades into the rotor_cap with the flat (leading) edge toward you

comments.text: Re. blades: you can just cut them out of a plastic plumbing pipe diagonally, therefore you get cheap blades that can be easily replaced in overwind accident.
comments.author: isee

comments.text: Hi, I write for Popular Mechanics and I'm working on a story about Thingiverse and 3D printing scientific equipment, in which I am going to mention this lovely turbine. Could I call or email you to get your comment on this device in particular and the practice of open source hardware sharing in general? My number is 212-649-2973 and my email is [email protected]
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: oh also a question what's the wing span on those aluminum blades
comments.author: terramir

comments.text: The blades are each 1 meter long for a 2-meter swept diameter.
comments.author: terramir

comments.text: why can't it be printed by a reprap would like an explanation on that one
comments.author: terramir

comments.text: A RepRap has a pretty small (I think it's like 10x10x10 cm) build envelope, which is way too small to make the blades or the mount in one piece. With a larger 3D printer you could actually make better blades since they would be lighter and you could print them with an aerofoil curve instead of just flat, but the design calls for CNC-milled blades since that's the cheapest and most accessible option.
comments.author: terramir

comments.text: Take a look at the Rostock printers...
comments.author: haydnv

comments.text: Very neat design, I'm going to see if anyone at my hackerspace is interested in this kind of thing, I'd love to build one. :-D
comments.author: haydnv

comments.text: Great! Let me know if you run into any problems.
comments.author: KazW

comments.text: Saved me designing this, thanks.
comments.author: DarkAlchemist

comments.text: Design your own anyways.  Games are copied every day, but it's the implementation details which make one game of the same genre of game better than another.  Having multiple designs to build and learn from would still be very beneficial to the community.
comments.author: DarkAlchemist

comments.text: Very cool!  I love the idea of people with 3-D printers being able to make other technologies that can directly benefit themselves and their communities. We need a lot more renewable energy tech everywhere and this is a really nice way for people that want it to gut the costs. Thank you.
comments.author: jpearce

comments.text:
Unfortunately I only had enough money to build one prototype, which was damaged in a fall. It may be a month or three before I can put another one together
